thread.title: OC won’t take West St. Mary for granted
thread.title_full: OC won’t take West St. Mary for granted

title: OC won’t take West St. Mary for granted
text:
OC won’t take West St. Mary for granted Bobby Ardoin 4:43 p.m. CDT October 7, 2015 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Opelousas Catholic head football coach Dane Charpentier says he isn’t being overly generous in praise for an opponent. 
It’s more like taking nothing for granted and speaking with genuine respect when it comes to a district opponent. 
With that mindset Charpentier’s Vikings (3-2, 1-1) travel to Baldwin for a District 5-2A game with West St. Mary (1-4, 1-1) Thursday night. 
Any perception of a mismatch, Charpentier said, is a thought far from reality, despite the overall record for the Wolf Pack. 
“It’s not like we’re going to be running through the tall grass. It’s more like running through a briar patch,” Charpentier said. 
There’s no reason for his team to be overconfident against an opponent averaging 10 points a game and was limited to six total points during the first three weeks of the season, said Charpentier. 
“West St. Mary rose up and beat Jeanerette (36-25) last week. They are improving with a new head coach (Clifton Armelin) and there is always going to be that transition period. 
“You look at the tape and they have some good players. You can see over the course of the season how they have improved and are working hard. 
“They have good size, good speed, good athletes,” Charpentier said. 
The Vikings are also the third St. Landry Parish team West St. Mary has played during the past five weeks. 
WSMH opened the season with a 23-0 loss to Beau Chene followed by a 34-0 defeat the next week in a game against Northwest High. 
OC meanwhile, has lost two games against Notre Dame and Central Catholic-Morgan City, teams that are ranked in the top 10 of their classifications. 
The Vikings have stuck with their running game offensively for most of the season, but during the past couple of games, OC has injected some new components into the backfield. 
In addition to starters Aaron Miller and Aaron Whipp, OC has used Evan Moody and Lyn Hebert as frequent rushing options. 
Hebert gained 96 yards on 10 carries in last Thursday’s 35-0 win over Sacred Heart. Moody gained 32 on nine attempts. 
“What we’ve been trying to do is keep (Whipp and Miller) fresh and especially keep (Whipp) ready on defense. 
You always want to develop that depth in the running game,” Charpentier said. 
One constant in the backfield for OC has been second-year starting quarterback David Labbe. 
Labbe is a frequent runner and last week ran for 78 yards on11 attempts and three touchdowns against Sacred Heart. Read or Share this story: http://www.dailyworld.com/story/sports/high-school/2015/10/07/oc-take-west-st-mary-granted/73543680/ TOP VIDEOS
